results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

The first part of this film briefly shows an outdoor art show before moving on to water ski jumping on the Yarra River – both are part of the ‘Moomba’ celebrations. The second part shows a road trip from Glenroy to Macedon ending at ‘Cameron Lodge’, Macedon all in Victoria.

Good views of the water ski jumping and the crowds watching from the banks. The road trip shows excellent views of small towns such as Keilor and Diggers Rest, vehicles passing on country roads and roadside scenes including telegraph poles.

Extensive views of the gardens of Cameron Lodge in Macedon including the rotunda, lake, stepping stones and family scenes in the garden.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 outdoor art show
00:00:44:00 Yarra River
00:01:00:00 the ‘Moomba’ festival on the riverbank
00:01:14:00 water skiing
00:02:00:00 water skiing over a jump
00:02:30:00 crowd watching from riverbank
00:03:40:00 title card ‘Glenroy to Macedon 4-3-61’
00:03:47:00 footage of car trip filmed from moving car showing country roads
00:04:38:00 car parked next to Keilor road sign. Good views of cars on road including VW beetle and Holdens, views of telegraph poles
00:05:05:00 road bridge with curved arch
00:05:10:00 ‘Keilor Hotel’ and parked cars, street scenes
00:05:20:00 Diggers Rest town scenes
00:05:40:00 countryside from moving car
00:06:35:00 Jacksons Creek bridge
00:07:28:00 small town with parked Holdens and BP service station
00:07:46:00 title card ‘Cameron Lodge Macedon 4-3-61’
00:07:52:00 views of Cameron Lodge and man walking in gardens
00:08:24:00 views of garden rotunda
00:08:37:00 two women and baby in lodge garden
00:08:40:00 man photographing garden
00:08:47:00 man in rotunda surrounded by lake, crossing stepping stones
00:09:21:00 group walk through lush vegetation including tree ferns
00:09:46:00 walking through lodge garden
00:10:03:00 children playing in rotunda and on stepping stones
00:10:46:00 group of children and adults on lakeside steps
00:11:10:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film titled ‘Sydney’, contains scenes around the Sydney Harbour and the Sydney Harbour Bridge, including the toll station, Circular Quay, the streets and traffic of the CBD and Toronga Park Zoo.

There are scenes are filmed from a high vantage point, probably the Bridge itself and from a boat or ferry on the Harbour.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 title ‘Sydney’
00:00:45:00 toll stations on the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:00:57:00 Circular Quay, yachts and scenes around the Harbour from a high vantage point
00:02:11:00 title card ‘Sydney’ followed by scenes of the city
00:03:25:00 Toronga Park and the zoo
00:03:30:00 pelicans on the water followed by koalas, monkeys, seals, penguins, hippopotamus and giraffe standing by a height chart
00:05:29:00 zebras, antlers, flamingoes, tortoises and an emu, lions and tigers, dingoes or dogs of some kind and deer
00:07:48:00 title card ‘Departure from Sydney’ followed by views around Sydney Harbour

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film is mostly focused on the Snowy Mountains Scheme in New South Wales, an integrated water and hydro-electric power utility constructed between 1949 and 1974, located in Australia’s Southern Alps.

There are also some scenes of travel around Brisbane in Queensland.

Frequent title cards assist the viewer with detail, particularly regarding the workings of the hydro Scheme.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Snowy Mountain Scheme 1957’
00:00:22:00 the Snowy Mountain Authority buildings
00:00:44:00 title card ‘Guthega Dam’ followed by views of the dam
00:01:45:00 views of the accommodation buildings
00:02:00:00 title card ‘Guthega Power Station’
00:02:14:00 several views of a large cement pipeline
00:02:55:00 title card ‘Island Bend’
00:03:11:00 a four wheel drive vehicle at the site
00:03:19:00 a Pioneer Express bus waiting for passengers
00:03:22:00 sign ‘Snowy Mountain Lookout’ followed by wide vistas of the mountains
00:03:44:00 title card ‘Adaminaby Dam’
00:04:03:00 trucks working in a quarry and the clearance of trees for the workings of the Scheme
00:04:50:00 workers atop a tower construction
00:05:15:00 sign for the contractors, ‘Etudes Et Enterprises’ at the T.I. power station
00:05:31:00 title card ‘Tumut Ponds’
00:05:48:00 mouths of tunnels into the mountainsides
00:06:27:00 title card ‘Cabramurra’
00:07:41:00 title card ‘Cooma Airport’
00:07:45:00 airplane for Butler Air Transport
00:08:14:00 title card ‘Queensland 1957’
00:08:19:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:08:50:00 title card ‘Mt Coot-Tha’
00:09:14:00 title card ‘Brisbane River’, followed by views of the river
00:09:55:00 ‘Koalas at Lone Pine’ followed by a koala sitting on a dog’s back, and kangaroos
00:10:35:00 ‘Glasshouse Mountains’
00:11:00:00 ‘Long Island’ and a map of the coast of Queensland showing the location
00:11:20:00 beach scenes and an open four wheel drive modified to take passengers from small boats to the shore and on to the holiday huts
00:12:24:00 fishing scenes and wooden boxes full of fish
00:12:40:00 title card ‘Visit to South Molle’
00:13:57:00 title card ‘Visit to Happy Bay’ followed by views around the beach and bay area
00:16:08:00 title card ‘Departure of Guests’ and the holiday visitors are taken on the modified jeep to a small boat, bound for the ferry

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film opens with a ‘red rattler’ train at Lilydale station, in Victoria. It is Christmas Day in 1970 and the filmmaker’s daughter Elenor Peach and her husband Ron are boarding the train. The ‘red rattler’ was the name affectionally given to the ‘Tait carriage’ wooden-bodied electric trains that ran in metropolitan Melbourne, Victoria, from 1919 to the early 1980s (named after the then Commissioner of Railways Sir Thomas Tait).

Most of the film captures a holiday around regional Victoria and include great examples of holiday life in the 1970s, such as men’s and women’s bathing suits, sunglasses, sunhats, beach umbrellas, surfing, picnics and station-wagon cars for travelling and camping at a creek among Australian tea trees.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a wonderful close-up of a ‘red rattler’ train pulled up at a station
00:00:25:00 a group of holiday makers sitting on camp chairs next to a creek
00:00:35:00 collecting water from the creek
00:00:57:00 close-ups of the holiday makers including a wonderful example of a handmade 1960s/1970s gingham smocking hat
00:01:50:00 a young woman in a bikini bathing suit and bathing cap enters the fast running creek water
00:02:12:00 swimming and a close-up of the 1960s/1970s rubber bathing cap which is covered in pink flowers
00:02:18:00 looking through insect netting to a man holding a baby (which lends an interesting effect)
00:02:45:00 young men in ‘cut off shorts’ fixing a Holden model car
00:02:53:00 lovely intergenerational picture of a very young baby held by an elderly age man who is wearing braces (rather than a belt)for his trousers of an earlier era
00:03:17:00 swimming along the creek and sitting on the bank
00:04:22:00 focus on a full head of hair ‘curlers’ as used at the time
00:04:29:00 views of rocky terrain and bush and a woman with a camera takes a photo of the filmmaker
00:05:45:00 rock climbing and views the Grampians mountain range (Geriwerd, Gariwerd) in Western Victoria
00:08:19:00 views of the township of Stawell in regional Victoria
00:08:58:00 title ‘Seascape’ written in sand followed by views of the sea and coastline, likely to be around the coastal town of Lorne in Victoria
00:09:55:00 surfboards strapped to a van followed by golfing on a cliff overlooking the sea
00:10:05:00 views of surfers in the water, a swimmer walking from the sea to her towel and the group of holiday makers sitting on the sand under a beach umbrella
00:10:46:00 taking a shot through a camera on a tripod on the sand
00:11:38:00 colourful beach umbrellas and bathers with a car of the era in the background
00:12:37:00 a roadside picnic
00:12:57:00 wonderful example of decorative sunglasses of the era
00:13:17:00 title ‘The End’ written in the sand

The ‘red rattler’ was the name affectionally given to the ‘Tait carriage’ wooden-bodied electric trains that ran in metropolitan Melbourne, Victoria, from 1919 to the early 1980s (named after the then Commissioner of Railways Sir Thomas Tait).

Most of the film captures a holiday around regional Victoria and include great examples of holiday life in the 1970s, such as men’s and women’s bathing suits, sunglasses, sunhats, beach umbrellas, surfing, picnics and station-wagon cars for travelling and camping at a creek among Australian tea trees.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a wonderful close-up of a ‘red rattler’ train pulled up at a station
00:00:25:00 a group of holiday makers sitting on camp chairs next to a creek
00:00:35:00 collecting water from the creek
00:00:57:00 close-ups of the holiday makers including a wonderful example of a handmade 1960s/1970s gingham smocking hat
00:01:50:00 a young woman in a bikini bathing suit and bathing cap enters the fast running creek water
00:02:12:00 swimming and a close-up of the 1960s/1970s rubber bathing cap which is covered in pink flowers
00:02:18:00 looking through insect netting to a man holding a baby (which lends an interesting effect)
00:02:45:00 young men in ‘cut off shorts’ fixing a Holden model car
00:02:53:00 lovely intergenerational picture of a very young baby held by an elderly age man who is wearing braces (rather than a belt)for his trousers of an earlier era
00:03:17:00 swimming along the creek and sitting on the bank
00:04:22:00 focus on a full head of hair ‘curlers’ as used at the time
00:04:29:00 views of rocky terrain and bush and a woman with a camera takes a photo of the filmmaker
00:05:45:00 rock climbing and views the Grampians mountain range (Geriwerd, Gariwerd) in Western Victoria
00:08:19:00 views of the township of Stawell in regional Victoria
00:08:58:00 title ‘Seascape’ written in sand followed by views of the sea and coastline, likely to be around the coastal town of Lorne in Victoria
00:09:55:00 surfboards strapped to a van followed by golfing on a cliff overlooking the sea
00:10:05:00 views of surfers in the water, a swimmer walking from the sea to her towel and the group of holiday makers sitting on the sand under a beach umbrella
00:10:46:00 taking a shot through a camera on a tripod on the sand
00:11:38:00 colourful beach umbrellas and bathers with a car of the era in the background
00:12:37:00 a roadside picnic
00:12:57:00 wonderful example of decorative sunglasses of the era
00:13:17:00 title ‘The End’ written in the sand

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows a family holiday along the east coast of Australia, beginning with the suspension bridge and dramatic cascades of water at the Hume Weir on the Victorian and New South Wales (NSW) border.

The family travels on to Timbertown near the town of Wauchope in NSW. Developed as a re-creation of an 1880-1910 working timber settlement, the tourist attraction ‘Timbertown’ was opened in the 1970s with some original buildings and some built to historic plans.

We also see a restored steam train, ‘The Green Hornet’ travel through bushland, a group of working bullocks and a glimpse of whip cracking. It’s then on to the Big Banana at Coffs Harbour, a Sikh Temple in NSW and some bushwalking.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:16:00 footbridge over the Hume Weir
00:00:30:00 close-up of the Hume Weir slipway followed by views around the Weir works
00:01:45:00 pelicans on the water
00:02:02:00 ‘Timbertown’ sign and a steam train with a great example of 1970s fashion ‘flares’ being worn in the foreground
00:02:15:00 children looking around ‘Timbertown’
00:02:25:00 a team of bullocks on a dusty road accompanied by a man carrying a large axe, followed by an old fashioned horse and cart
00:02:55:00 a demonstration of manual short plank splitting
00:03:25:00 children enjoy a ride through the trees on a steam train
00:03:50:00 whip cracking exhibition followed by ‘The Green Hornet’ in close up as it steams by
00:04:15:00 close up of the bullock yoke workings followed by a demonstration in a small arena of the bullocks team at work hauling a single large log
00:05:11:00 ‘The Big Banana’ and admirers at Coffs Harbour
00:05:40:00 sign for ‘The Vincent Tree’ after which the camera pans up a very tall tree trunk
00:06:54:00 botannical sign for ‘Yellow Carabeen Sloanea Woollisii’ and views of the tree
00:07:30:00 the family pose in the stocks of an old set of buildings which could be Middle Head Fort on the NSW coast
00:08:29:00 seabirds and various views of coastline and sea
00:09:13:00 the family on the beach
00:09:20:00 sign for the ‘Guru Nanak Sikh Temple’ rests on a brick wall, followed by the Temple
00:09:58:00 dramatic views of a ravinne and waterfall
00:10:30:00 children playing in an ‘Apex Park’ playground

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows family holidays and recreational activities including trips to the beach, road trips to regional Victoria, children’s playgrounds (including swings and slippery slides) farm animals, pets and women’s tennis.

There is footage of Melbourne during the 1956 Olympics, showing athletes warming up, relay track events, Flinders Street and St Paul’s Cathedral with Olympic decorations.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:57:00 bird’s eye view of 1940s cars on country dirt road
00:01:13:00 stationary 1940s car on dirt road, with passenger looking out window and driver posing in front of the car
00:01:18:00 wooden fire tower
00:02:09:00 children and mother walking down stone steps of picnic ground. Good fashion shots.
00:02:16:00 parked 1940s car
00:02:45:00 country look-out point with telescope and vintage car
00:02:56:00 two children posing for camera (good vintage fashion shots)
00:03:05:00 hobby farm with children and adults patting goats and cows
00:03:51:00 children in birthday party clothes
00:04:09:00 children on slippery slide

00:06:07:00 farm animals and pets

00:09:19:00 c1940/1950 Women’s doubles tennis match

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film contains some of the Hayes family favourites – their assorted pets including the star of many of the films, Ticka the cockatoo, their farm animals and views of the areas surrounding their home in Heathmont. There is also a brief visit to the beach.

A feature of the film is some early views of Ringwood shops and traffic including good examples of cars of the day and the very new looking ‘Holden Bill Paterson Motors’. Bill Paterson was a successful racing car driver of his era. We also see advertising signs of the day such as ‘Whelan the Wrecker’ and ‘Dickies’ and a vintage ‘red rattler’ train crossing the Yarra so likely to be the Port Melbourne/St Kilda line now a lightrail.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows snippets of family life while at play, at birthday celebrations and on holiday. We see the family drive across the bridge to Phillip Island and enjoy swimming and canoeing at the beach there. The reel also includes scenes of caravan camping, koalas and a trip to the war memorial at Mount Macedon. The family enjoy games of tennis, ball games and swings and roundabouts at a playground. The film includes good examples of fashion, Austin cars and recreational activities of the time.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of Hayes family life across the generations to include the grandchildren. The first segment is titled, ‘The Animals’ and features the family pets including dogs, calves, cows and the audacious cockatoo named Ticka, at home in suburban Heathmont in Melbourne’s outer east.

There are travel scenes of Narracan East, King River and the ‘Astor’ motel at Albury where Charles takes some dramatic footage of the Hume Weir. The family were keen tennis players and visited Albury at Easter so likely took part in the Albury Tennis Association competitions.

As well are some beach scenes at Point Leo, Golden Beach and Frankston where we see one of the dogs up to its neck in sand and some great examples of sixties bathing suits and sun hats.

The filmmaker shows some of the great cars at the time so that we see examples of 1960s and 1970s models. A brief segment from the Moomba Festival in Melbourne shows the ‘Frankston by the Sea’ song lyrics on one of the floats at the time.

Charles also shows the family’s involvement in tennis, trying out an early model Cortina car, and celebrating ‘Elinor’s 21st’ in white gloves and evening gowns and a display of the presents.

A particular feature of the film is the footage of ‘Southgate Fountain’ public art work by Robin Boyd (now demolished to make way for the redevelopment of Southgate on Melbourne’s Yarra river).

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.
